page.title: 03Local History at Bromp on S
page.content: At Catterick racecourse there is an old{Roman wall,}the remains of a camp near a ford over the Swale. The first{Domesday Book}mentions the Anglo-Saxon settlement of 'Brumpton' from 'broom' meaning shrub and 'tun' for a farmstead or village. There has been a{bridge}over the Swale at Catterick certainly since the C15th as a hotel was built then. As Brompton lies near the A1 it became part of the Richmond to Lancaster{Turnpike}in 1751. Records show that{craftsmen}such as blacksmiths, millers,curriers and wheelwrights worked here. There was a brewery here until 1956 and a tannery. There was also a{railway}through the village to join the main East Coast line near Darlington until it was closed about 17 years ago.
